issues.description: The problem text explicitly instructs students to implement the helper method singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal) as public for testing, but both the template and the reference solution declare this method as private. This mismatch between the required visibility (public) and the code provided (private) is likely to confuse students and may break automated tests that expect a public helper method.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the helper method's visibility consistent with the problem text. Either (A) update the template and reference solution to declare the helper as public: public void singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal) { ... }, or (B) if the intended visibility is private, update the problem text to remove the instruction to make it public (and mention that tests will access the song only via singFarmSong()). Option A is recommended to match the testing hint in the problem text.

issues.description: The problem statement contains an internal contradiction: the UML diagram shows singFarmSongVerse(animal: Animal):void as private (the '-' prefix), while the textual instructions explicitly ask students to implement singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal) as public for easier testing. This inconsistency in the specification can confuse students about the intended visibility.
issues.suggested_fix: Clarify the problem statement so UML and textual instructions agree. Either change the UML to show the method as public (use '+' in the diagram) or remove/alter the textual instruction so both indicate the method should be private. Prefer making the UML show it as public if tests/assignment expect public access.

issues.description: The template's singFarmSongVerse declaration lacks the Animal parameter (the parameter is commented out: /*Animal animal*/), while the UML and the solution expect a signature that accepts an Animal parameter (singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal)). The missing parameter in the template is a structural mismatch that will force students to change the method signature and could cause confusion about the intended API.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the template so the helper method has the intended parameter: change the declaration to (and adjust visibility per the previous issue): public void singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal) { ... } (or private if you choose to keep it private). Ensure the method signature matches the UML and the solution so students and tests agree on the API.
